title: Which Allergy Medication Is Best for You?

content: When you have allergies, you have many options for treating the symptoms. It’s important to know which treatments do what and when to turn to one option versus another. Your allergies may bother your sinuses, eyes, nasal passages, airways, skin, or a combination of these. The treatment you choose should address the symptoms you have.

content_blocks.text: When you have allergies, you have many options for treating the symptoms. It’s important to know which treatments do what and when to turn to one option versus another. Your allergies may bother your sinuses, eyes, nasal passages, airways, skin, or a combination of these. The treatment you choose should address the symptoms you have.

sections.heading: Antihistamines
content: Antihistamines are the most common medications for allergies. They target histamine, a chemical in your body, and block it from attaching to certain cells. Histamines tell cells to react to allergens, the substances that cause an allergic reaction. This starts a chain reaction that increases inflammation and blood flow in your body. Because antihistamines stop this action, they prevent allergy symptoms such as: Congestion Excessive coughing or sneezing Runny nose Watery eyes Facial or bodily swelling Skin rashes Gastrointestinal issues (nausea , diarrhea , or vomiting) Anaphylaxis, a life-threatening allergic reaction Antihistamines work best when you take them before you feel allergy symptoms. Once they’re in your blood, they can protect against allergens and prevent the release of histamines from happening. Their effects build up over time.

sections.heading: Types of antihistamines
content: For example, if you know you have allergies to pollen from a specific season, start taking an antihistamine before that season starts. Antihistamines come in several forms, including: Eye drops. To treat itchy, red, swollen eyes. Examples include: Ketotifen (Alaway, Zaditor) Olopatadine (Pataday) Nasal sprays. To ease sneezing, an itchy or runny nose, sinus congestion, and postnasal drip. Examples include: Azelastine (Astepro) Olopatadine Oral medications (tablets or capsules). For widespread treatment of allergies including runny nose, itchy or watery eyes, hives , and swelling. Some oral antihistamines make you drowsy because of the cells they attach to. These include: Brompheniramine (Dimetapp) Chlorpheniramine (Chlor-Trimeton) Diphenhydramine (Benadryl) Hydroxyzine (Atarax and Vistaril) Antihistamines that are much less likely to cause drowsiness include: Cetirizine (Zyrtec Allergy) Desloratadine (Clarinex) Fexofenadine (Allegra Allergy) Levocetirizine (Xyzal Allergy 24HR) Loratadine (Alavert, Claritin)

sections.heading: Corticosteroids
content: Corticosteroids are powerful medicines that turn down your immune system and reduce swelling in your body. This helps with allergy symptoms such as: Itchy nose, mouth, eyes, or throat Runny nose Sneezing Tearing eyes Nasal congestion Skin allergies such as eczema or hives Asthma Hay fever (allergic rhinitis)

sections.heading: Types of corticosteroids
content: Some corticosteroids you can get over the counter and some are prescription only. Corticosteroids come in many forms. The more directly a corticosteroid works on a problem, the fewer side effects it has. Nasal sprays. These go directly into your nostrils and reduce swelling so you can breathe. They’re the most effective treatment for seasonal allergies and don’t cause as many side effects as oral medications that go through your whole body. Corticosteroids can be delivered as a spray directly into the nasal cavities to relieve allergy-related inflammation. Examples include: Budesonide (Rhinocort) Flunisolide Fluticasone furoate (Flonase Sensimist) Fluticasone propionate (Flonase Allergy Relief) Mometasone (Nasonex) Triamcinolone (Nasacort Allergy 24HR) Systemic corticosteroids (pill, tablet, liquid, IV). These go through your whole body, and as a result can have the most severe side effects. Doctors use them to treat the most serious allergy symptoms such as anaphylaxis. They aren’t good for long-term use because of their side effects. Examples include: Methylprednisolone (Medrol) Prednisolone (Prelone) Prednisone

sections.heading: Inhalers.
content: These are the treatment of choice for controlling asthma . As corticosteroids go into your lungs, they reduce swelling so you can breathe. They help treat attacks and also prevent further attacks. Examples include: Beclomethasone (Qvar Redihaler) Budesonide (Pulmicort Flexhaler) Ciclesonide (Alvesco) Fluticasone (Flovent, ArmonAir Digihaler) Mometasone (Asmanex Twisthaler) Eye drops. These can treat burning and itching eyes. You may need to see an ophthalmologist if you take them. Examples include: Loteprednol (Alrex, Lotemax) Prednisolone (Omnipred, Pred Forte) Creams. You can put these on your skin to treat allergic reactions like itching, scaling, or a change in your skin color. Examples include: Betamethasone (Dermabet, Diprolene) Desonide (DesOwen) Fluocinolone (Synalar) Hydrocortisone (Locoid, Micort-HC) Mometasone Triamcinolone

sections.heading: Biologic Medications
content: Biologic medications are drugs that are derived from living organisms, like proteins and genes. Biologics for allergies are also called allergen immunotherapy. These treatments introduce your body to allergens slowly over time and help change how your body responds. Doctors often prescribe these treatments for asthma , sinusitis, hives , and food allergies. Types of biologic medications Because of the way allergen immunotherapy works, a doctor will need to monitor you while you take it as the dose is increased.

sections.heading: Shots.
content: You get these every two to four weeks, year-round. Examples include: Dupilumab (Dupixent) for asthma, sinus pressure, and allergic skin conditions Omalizumab (Xolair) for asthma or hives when other medicines don't help Mepolizumab (Nucala) for asthma and sinus discomfort Pills and liquids. These may be a choice for peanut allergies in children, dust mites, or hay fever. Each treatment involves the allergen it’s treating. Examples include: Peanut allergy powder (Palforzia) House dust mite allergen extract (Odactra) Short ragweed pollen extract (Ragwitek) Sweet vernal, orchard, perennial rye, timothy, and Kentucky blue grass mixed pollens allergen extract (Oralair) Timothy grass pollen allergen extract (Grastek)

sections.heading: Leukotriene Inhibitors
content: These medications are also called leukotriene receptor agonists. They work similarly to antihistamines. But instead of blocking histamines, the chemical they block is leukotriene. Leukotrienes cause symptoms such as: Coughing Extra mucus and fluid in your chest and throat Inflammation or swelling in your airway Tight muscles in your airway Tightness in your chest Wheezing or difficulty breathing

sections.heading: Types of leukotriene inhibitors
content: You can only get them by prescription from your doctor. A doctor might prescribe these when you’re dealing with: Allergies (allergic rhinitis) Allergic asthma Exercise-induced asthma When leukotriene inhibitors block leukotriene, they can help you: Breathe more easily Exercise more easily if you have a breathing condition Keep your airway open Reduce mucus in your chest and throat Prevent breathing trouble from allergic reactions and asthma attacks Reduce the number and severity of reactions and attacks Leukotriene inhibitors come only in pill form. Examples include: Montelukast (Singulair) to treat asthma and allergic rhinitis Zafirlukast (Accolate) to treat asthma Zileuton (Zyflo) to treat asthma

content: Mast cell stabilizers block the release of chemicals in the immune system that lead to allergic reactions. Doctors will typically suggest these options after you’ve tried antihistamines and they haven’t worked. Types of mast cell stabilizers Nasal sprays you can get over the counter. An example is: Cromolyn Eye drops you get through prescription. Examples include: Cromolyn Lodoxamide (Alomide) Nedocromil

sections.heading: Types of decongestants
content: Nasal sprays. These give you immediate relief from nasal congestion. You shouldn’t use them for more than three to five days in a row. If you use them longer than that, you may cause a “rebound” effect and make congestion worse. Examples include: Oxymetazoline (Afrin) Tetrahydrozoline Pills. These can treat seasonal allergies. Some are decongestants only, such as: Pseudoephedrine (Sudafed) Others are a combination of decongestant medication plus other medications such as an expectorant (cough medicine), pain relievers, or antihistamine. Examples include: Acetaminophen/guaifenesin/pseudoephedrine (Tylenol Sinus Severe Congestion Daytime) Cetirizine and pseudoephedrine (Zyrtec-D 12 Hour) Desloratadine and pseudoephedrine (Clarinex-D 12 Hour) Fexofenadine and pseudoephedrine (Allegra-D) Loratadine and pseudoephedrine (Claritin-D) Ibuprofen/pseudoephedrine (Advil Cold and Sinus)

content: If you have mild to moderate allergy symptoms, start with over-the-counter options.

content: These tips can help you in the pharmacy aisle: Nondrowsy oral antihistamines can give you general allergy relief with fewer side effects than options that make you sleepy. Use nasal corticosteroid sprays if you’re dealing with a clogged nose. Antihistamine eye drops are a good option for eye allergy symptoms. Use combination medications only if you deal with all the symptoms they treat. Otherwise stick to standalone medications and treat only what you have. Talk to the pharmacist to be sure the treatments you choose don’t interact with each other. For moderate to severe allergies, see your doctor so they can help get you on the right treatment track.
